Broken into separate sentences.text: This is the Mishnah broken into separate sentences. Click each part to learn more:

tokens.text: האיש מקדש את בתו כשהיא נערה בו ובשלוחו.
האיש מקדש את בתו כשהיא נערה בו ובשלוחו.

Required background information.text: This Mishnah presumes familiarity with the

Halachic steps of marriage.text: In Jewish law, a state of marriage is produced by two steps,

kiddushin.text: The first step of Jewish marriage is called

, the woman is designated to the man for marriage and would need a halachic divorce in order to remarry. However, the couple is not yet married, and may not live together or have physical contact. The first Mishnah of
discusses the different ways in which a man and woman can produce a state of
is sometimes translated as "engagement" although the binding nature of
is one difference between it and ordinary engagement.

nisuyin.text: The second step of Jewish marriage is called
, the couple must create a state of
in order to be formally married. In the times of the Gemara
might be done a year after
are done in the same wedding ceremony. Typically
is done by having the wife enter the residence of the groom, either his actual residence, or more commonly the

Concept of shlichus.text: , there are various actions a person can do that produce
consequences, such as buying and selling goods, or doing a
, we will see that some of these actions can be performed by an emissary, or
, who is designated beforehand by the individual, and the individual is credited with the action the emissary performs. Which actions can be done via
will be the primary topic of this Mishnah and the Gemaras that discuss it.

Position in the perek.text: This is the first Mishnah in the second
began by discussing the different methods a man can use to be
a woman, and this Mishnah will continue to discuss related topics.

Topic in halacha.text: This Mishnah will discuss which aspects of the marriage process can be done via a
. Think to yourself now, what parts would you guess can be done by
, and which parts would you think one wouldn't be able to do via

Consider what we would think the halacha.text: The first clause of the Mishnah is discussing whether a man can create
with a woman via a messenger without himself being present. Before reading on, stop and ask yourself, do you think this would work? Why or why not?

How do you know where the first clause e.text: How do we know where the first clause of the Mishnah ends? By reading the Mishnah, we should notices some similar-looking words being repeated:

tokens.text: את בתו כשהיא נערה בו ובשלוחו

How do you know where the first clause e.text: Based on this pattern, we should be able to recognize that the Mishnah is composed of three similar parts, and we can begin by focusing on the first one:

tokens.text: האשה מתקדשת בה ובשלוחה האיש מקדש את בתו כשהיא נערה בו ובשלוחו

Individual words.text: Next we need to understand the individual words of the first clause, you can select one to learn more:

האיש.text: . (Try reading the "possible meanings" of all the words in the sentence before looking at the "actual meaning" of any word, so that you can practice figuring it out yourself.)

Smaller words that might be part of האיש.text: Maybe האיש is composed of smaller words:

tokensOfLine.text: There is an Aramaic word הא which means "that"
There is an Aramaic word האי which means "this"
There is a Hebrew word אש meaning "fire"
There is a Hebrew word איש meaning "man."

Actual meaning of האיש.text: The word האיש is composed of

Other possibilities.text: We are reading a Mishnah, so we know we are reading Hebrew and not Aramaic, and so we shouldn't think the word האיש might be related to the Aramaic words הא or האי. Nevertheless, if there would exist a

spelled נאש, then the האיש could have been a past tense verb from that shoresh, (the same way נפל can become הִפִּיל), however, there is no such shoresh, so we know that can't be the answer. (For advanced readers, this kind of verb is called a

The word איש.text: The word איש in Hebrew means "man."

The prefix ה meaning \"the\".text: The prefix ה in front of a noun in Hebrew is similar to the English word "the."

Two verb forms that are spelled exactly.text: like אכל can produce multiple types of past-tense verbs, and one type would look like אָכַל, and one type would look like אִכֵּל, and because the Gemara doesn't have vowels, if you see three shoresh letters together like אכל, you might be looking at one of these two types of past-tense verb. (For advanced readers, אָכַל is the past-tense form of a

Actual meaning of מקדש.text: The word מקדש here means for a man to create a status of
with a woman prior to marriage.

Grammatical explanation of מקדש.text: For those interested in grammar, the word מקדש is the the

Parts of speech.text: The word מקדש can function as a noun, meaning "someone who makes something holy", a verb, someone or something "is making holy," or an adjective, something has "the quality of making something holy."

Possible meanings of בו.text: Here are some guesses at the meaning of this word:

tokensOfLine.text: A ו can sometimes make an "oh" sound, and there is a common verb in Hebrew pronounced "bo" that means "to come," so maybe this is a conjugation of that verb.
There is also a prefix ב that can mean "in," "with," "on," "via," or "at the time of," and there are various suffixes you can attach to it that indicate what is being refered to (ie "on/with/via"

Actual meaning of בו.text: The word בו here means "via himself," and there is a

Grammatical explanation of בו.text: For those interested in grammar, בו is
to indicate he is doing something "via
." We know it isn't the verb בוא meaning "comes" because even though it is pronounced the same as בו, that verb has an א in it.

The prefix ו.text: The prefix ו usually means "and," but can also mean "or."

The word שלוח.text: The word שלוח means "someone or something that is sent." For those interested in grammar, it is [masculine singular] of the [
passive participle tense of the shoresh שלח].

The noun suffix ו.text: The suffix ו when applied to a noun means "of him" or "of it."

Literal translation.text: Once we know what all the individual words mean, we can produce a literal translation:

tokens.text: , via himself or via his messenger.

That it says \"bo u'b'shlucho\".text: In order to understand what is interesting about this wording, let's observe that there are
several things you can mean when giving examples

tokens.text: several things you can mean when giving examples

That it says \"bo u'b'shlucho\".targetSubtopic: Several things you can mean when giving examples

That it says \"bo u'b'shlucho\".text: whether we know from the Mishnah which form of specificity is meant by "bo u'b'shlucho"

tokens.text: whether we know from the Mishnah which form of specificity is meant by "bo u'b'shlucho"

That it says \"bo u'b'shlucho\".targetSubtopic: Whether we know from the Mishnah which form of specificity is meant by "bo u'b'shlucho"

Several things you can mean when giving.text: If I tell you "you're invited to come drive to my wedding," I might mean one of three things:

tokensOfLine.text: A diyuk: I am telling you that you are only invited to come to my wedding if you come by car.
Lav davka: I am giving an example of how you could come, but what I mean is that any way is fine
Biggest chiddush: I am telling you that you can come any way,

driving, implying that for some reason it is more surprising that you'd be allowed to drive than other examples, and that all the more so it is also fine to use less-surprising forms of transportation.

Whether we know from the Mishnah which f.text: When the Mishnah gives an example of how something is done, does it generally mean for you to understand it as a diyuk, a lav-davka example, or as the biggest chiddush, and all the more so the din applies to less surprising cases?

What does \"being mekadesh\" mean here?.text: We find here a klal of mishnayos that a "present tense" statement means a psak, and so "the man is being mekadesh himself or with an emissary" in this context means "the man is
to be mekadesh, himself or with an emissary."

Why does it say the man?.text: If the Mishnah wanted to say "any man can be mekadesh an isha using these methods," why did it say "
man can be mekadesh", as if only some specific man can do it, instead of saying "
man can be mekadesh," ie any man? (Then it would read: איש מקדש, instead of האיש מקדש, because

Why does it say the man?.enclosingSubtopic: Why does it say the man?

Why does it say the man?.text: by default have an indefinite article

tokens.text: by default have an indefinite article

Why does it say the man?.targetSubtopic: By default have an indefinite article
Why does it say the man?.enclosingSubtopic: Why does it say the man?
